title: Muslim teacher refuses to appear on Good Morning Britain because of Piers Morgan and his 'links' to Donald Trump
text:

A teacher who was barred entry to the US has refused to appear on a morning TV programme because of its co-host Piers Morgan's friendship with President Donald Trump. 
Juhel Miah opted out of an interview with the Good Morning Britain presenter because he said he was worried about the Mr Morgan's "agenda". 
Mr Miah was travelling with a group from Llangatwg Comprehensive School, in Neath, Wales, on a trip to New York when he was removed from the aircraft in Reykjavik, Iceland. 
The 25-year-old said he had his luggage taken from him and was forced to stay in an “horrendous hotel” before school officials booked him on a flight back to the UK, Wales Online reports. 
But the Good Morning Britain presenter appeared to call into question respected maths teacher Mr Miah’s claim that he was made to “feel like a criminal”. Read More Piers Morgan rants about JK Rowling AGAIN as he reignites feud with Harry Potter dig Piers Morgan is renowned for his controversial comments (Photo: Rex Features) 
Piers Morgan wrote: “If it’s how he says it is, absolutely outrageous. But USA immigration has been doing this since 9/11 to a lot of Muslims.” 
The teacher hit back and said the incident was as he had described. 
He wrote: “It’s EXACTLY how I said it happened. I just want an explanation as to why. If what you said is true, that’s just not good enough.” 
Mr Miah said: “I declined Good Morning Britain because of Piers Morgan and his agenda and his links to Donald Trump. I told the programme I did not want to be on with Piers Morgan.” 
President Trump had tried to block travel by people living in seven predominately Muslim countries, including Iraq, Syria, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, and Yemen but it was scrapped following a successful legal challenge. Read More Nigel Farage admits he's "difficult" husband as he discusses love, Brexit and being “most hated figure” in politics Donald Trump wants to clamp down on the number of Muslims entering the US (Photo: PA) 
Mr Trump has now signed a revised executive order reducing it to six majority Muslim nations, which now exempts Iraq, after an intense review from the State Department to improve vetting of Iraqi citizens in a link-up with the Iraqi government. The order will take effect on March 16. 
A petition, created by Tom Reeve, has been set up in a bid to win an apology from the US Government for Mr Miah which has already gathered more than 800 signatures. 
Mr Miah, from Swansea, said he had been overwhelmed by the support and said he needed 10,000 names on the petition to have a Government response. Read More UK Muslim schoolteacher removed from flight after being denied entry to USA following Trump immigration ban Mr Miah was on a school trip with students from Llangatwg Comprehensive School (Photo: Google Maps) 
“I’ve had a lot of support and a lot of people from America who have apologised. I have had so many letters and emails I haven’t read them all, it’s quite moving. The support has been incredible. 
“Tom Reeve tweeted me and told me he had set up a petition. We need to get 10,000 signatures and that is going to be a challenge in itself.” 
He said he had raised his case with his MP Carolyn Harris, who represents Swansea East, over fears that travelling to other destinations on holiday would become an issue as his passport would be flagged. Read More US immigrants 'living in fear' as Donald Trump's crackdown sees hundreds arrested in raids He says he was removed from the aircraft in Iceland and made to feel 'like a criminal' (Photo: Ullstein Bild) 
Mr Miah said that although he felt “shocked” and “disappointed” over his treatment he would like to visit the US and to “get his name cleared.” 
“I have never been to the US, that’s why I was looking forward to going,” he added. “I am not getting an explanation for what happened." Like us on Facebook
